title: 105_s205
content: The "Citizen Congress Act" limits retirement coverage for members of Congress. The "Citizen Congress Act" restricts Congressional members from participating in the Civil Service Retirement System or the Federal Employees' Retirement System, except for the Thrift Savings Plan within a 12-year period. Refunds can still be made under certain circumstances. The "Citizen Congress Act" prohibits Congressional members from joining the Civil Service Retirement System or the Federal Employees' Retirement System, except for the Thrift Savings Plan within 12 years. Refunds can be made if a member becomes ineligible to participate in the retirement systems. Annuities based on prior service are not affected by this restriction. The "Citizen Congress Act" prohibits Congressional members from joining certain retirement systems, except for the Thrift Savings Plan within 12 years. Annuities based on prior service are preserved, with certain limitations on service and pay considered. The "Citizen Congress Act" restricts Congressional members from enrolling in specific retirement systems after 12 years, except for the Thrift Savings Plan. Annuities and benefits for individuals based on separation from Congress are preserved to maintain their entitlements as of the enactment date. Regulations for implementation may be issued by the Office of Personnel Management and the Executive Director. The "Citizen Congress Act" limits Congressional members' participation in retirement systems after 12 years, except for the Thrift Savings Plan. The terms "Member of Congress" and "Member" are defined under title 5, United States Code. This section does not apply to savings plans or matters outside of specific chapters in the Code. SEC. 3. Disclosure of estimates of federal retirement benefits for Members of Congress. The Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 1965 is amended to require the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives to report on individual contributions made by Members of Congress to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund and the Thrift Savings Fund, as well as provide an estimate of the annuity each Member would receive based on their federal service. The section specifies the information required for calculating federal retirement benefits for Members of Congress based on years of service and age at retirement. It will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. ELIMINATION OF AUTOMATIC ANNUITY ADJUSTMENTS FOR MEMBERS OF CONGRESS. The annuity portion based solely on service as a Member of Congress will not receive COLA adjustments. SEC. 5. ELIMINATION OF AUTOMATIC PAY ADJUSTMENTS FOR MEMBERS OF CONGRESS. Repeals pay adjustments for Members of Congress. SEC. 6. ROLLCALL VOTE FOR ANY CONGRESSIONAL PAY RAISE. SEC. 6. Rollcall vote required for any congressional pay raise. SEC. 7. Travel awards from official travel of House of Representatives members, officers, or employees can only be used for official travel. SEC. 7 restricts the use of travel awards accrued from official travel of House of Representatives members, officers, or employees to only be used for official travel. The Committee on House Oversight is authorized to create regulations for this section. In section 3210 of title 39, United States Code, amendments are made regarding mass mailings by Members of Congress. The intent is that Members of Congress cannot use franked mail for mass mailings. Technical and conforming amendments are also made to the code. The amendments repeal certain subparagraphs and sections related to legislative branch appropriations acts. The effective date for these changes is at the beginning of the next Congress after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 9. RESTRICTIONS ON USE OF MILITARY AIR COMMAND BY MEMBERS OF CONGRESS. Restrictions on provision of air transportation to Members of Congress are outlined in Chapter 157 of title 10, United States Code. Members of Congress can only receive transportation in a Military Air Command aircraft under specific conditions, such as space availability, necessity due to inaccessible destinations, or as the least costly option. The provision of air transportation to Members of Congress is restricted under Chapter 157 of title 10, United States Code. Military aircraft can be used by Members of Congress if it is the least expensive option or necessary due to inaccessible destinations. The destination cannot be selected to accommodate the travel plans of the Member of Congress. The term 'aircraft' includes fixed-wing airplanes and helicopters. Restrictions on air transportation for Members of Congress under Chapter 157 of title 10, United States Code do not apply to Members currently receiving transportation until their travel plans are completed. Prohibition on provision of medical and dental care to Members of Congress in any uniformed service facility unless eligible or on emergency basis. Prohibition on providing medical and dental care to Members of Congress in uniformed service facilities, with exceptions for those already receiving care. Elimination of reserved parking areas at Washington National Airport and Washington Dulles International Airport. Effective 30 days after enactment, the Airports Authority must stop providing free reserved parking to Members of Congress, Government officials, and diplomats at Washington National Airport and Washington Dulles International Airport. A new parking policy will ensure equal access for the public without preferential treatment for these individuals. Definitions of key terms are provided.
